did.unittitle: Henry Savage papers

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Maggs Brothers Ltd. on the James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection Fund, 2015.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Henry Savage papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Henry Savage Papers. James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: Henry Savage (1879-1965)
bioghist.p: English author and editor Henry Savage worked for various literary journals in London in the years before World War II. Savage is perhaps best known for his biography of his friend, poet Richard Middleton, Richard Middleton: The man and his work (London: Cecil Palmer, 1922). Other works written by Savage include a novel, How to manage our women (London: Humphrey Toulmin, 1930), an autobiography, The receding shore (London: Grayson & Grayson, 1933) and the poetry collections, Escapes and escapades (London: The Pomegranate Press, 1915), Songs and satires (The Renaissance Press, 1946), and Winged phallus . Works edited by Savage include Richard Middleton's letters to Henry Savage (London: The Mandrake Press, 1929) and The love letters of Henry VIII (London: Allan Wingate, 1949). Savage retired first to Winchelsea, in Sussex, England, then to Capri and Tenerife.
Biographical information taken from Moore, Harry T., "D. H. Lawrence to Henry Savage: An introductory note," The Yale University Library Gazette 34, 1 (July 1959).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Henry Savage papers consists of writings, correspondence, and other papers relating to English author and editor Henry Savage. Writings feature printed versions of shorter works by Savage and several drafts. Printed versions of essays and reviews appear to have been assembled for possible publication as a collection or selection of writings. Other writings by Savage include drafts of a late work of reminiscences, "Promenade picaresque," and page proofs for a work of verse entitled Winged phallus .

Series II. Correspondence includes correspondence with authors, booksellers, publishers, literary scholars, friends, and family. The Henry Savage Correspondence includes all incoming and outgoing letters between Savage and others. There are incoming letters from Armin Arnold, William Heinemann Ltd., René MacColl, Burns Singer, Wilfrid C. Thorley, and Colin Wilson, and outgoing letters to "Bess" Greville, Guy Rayne Savage (Henry's son), and Valentine Watts. Some letters to and from Guy Rayne Savage document his service as executor of his father's literary estate. Additional correspondents include Bertram Rota Ltd. and E. L. McAdam.

Other Papers contains clippings, journals, photographs, printed material, and personal papers. The series features a run of 26 handwritten journals spanning three full decades from 1933 to 1963. A photograph album and photographs contain images of Savage, family, and unidentified others.
Collection material is chiefly in English; with some materials in Spanish.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Writings, 1911-1964. II. Correspondence, 1896-1990. III. Other Papers, 1900-1980.

did.unittitle: Writings

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Essays and Reviews, Other Writings, and Writings of Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. Writings, features printed versions of shorter works by Savage and several drafts. Printed versions of "essays and reviews" appear to have been assembled for possible publication as a collection or selection of writings. The writings, which date chiefly from the early 1920s, appear in three separate publications, Book notes illustrated , Bookman's journal , and The new witness . These writings, now arranged alphabetically by title, are attributed to Savage and to various pseudonyms. Pseudonyms include Adrian Harley, Anthony Scrope, and Worthington Cadogan. Many of the titles published under a pseudonym are initialed, "HS".
Other writings by Savage include drafts of a late work of reminiscences, "Promenade picaresque," a marked copy of Songs and satires , and page proofs for a work of verse entitled Winged phallus .

Correspondence

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Henry Savage Correspondence, Guy Rayne Savage Correspondence, and Other Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. includes correspondence with authors, booksellers, publishers, literary scholars, friends, and family. The first subseries, Henry Savage Correspondence, includes all incoming and outgoing letters between Savage and others. There are incoming letters from Armin Arnold, William Heinemann Ltd., René MacColl, Burns Singer, Wilfrid C. Thorley, and Colin Wilson, and outgoing letters to "Bess" Greville, Guy Rayne Savage (Henry's son), and Valentine Watts. There are over one hundred autograph manuscript letters, signed, from Henry to his son, most dating from the mid-1950s onward, after Savage had settled in Tenerife. Letters discuss family, writing and writing projects, books he is reading, trips, and various other aspects of life in Tenerife, such as social activities, his health, and the weather.

Other letters to and from Guy Rayne Savage comprise the second Correspondence subseries. Many letters post-dating Henry's death in 1965 document Guy Savage's service as executor of his father's literary estate. Additional correspondents include Bertram Rota Ltd. and E. L. McAdam.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alhabetically by material type and heading.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III. contains clippings, journals, photographs, printed material, and additional personal papers. The series features a run of 26 handwritten journals spanning three full decades from 1933 to 1963. A photograph album and loose photographs contain images of Savage, family, and unidentified others. Most photographs in the collection show Savage as an older man, and would appear to date from the mid-1950s forward.
